data.title: Why These Lifelong Learners Are Upskilling Online
data.meta_description: These three lifelong learners have been upskilling online on OpenLearning to boost their resume and gain new skills.
data.text:
This blog post is from our themed series on Malaysian Contentpreneurship in conjunction with the Malaysian national day celebrations. This week, we‚Äôre highlighting Malaysian learners who are taking the opportunity to upskill online.

The new normal has revealed that education is no longer a ‚Äúone-and-done‚Äù event. As it is becoming evident that we need to regularly update our skills and knowledge for a fast-moving world, many Malaysians are also realising the wide range of opportunities presented by online learning and upskilling.

Education providers and contentpreneurs from all walks of life too have leveraged on online platforms to make a difference: many have started running online courses as a way to share their knowledge and experience to inspire and help others.

One such example is Norizan Sharif, whom we have written about in this article. After a successful career in the public sector, Norizan wanted to give back to the community by helping fresh graduates to enhance their soft skills.

What keeps me going is to see young people get a job, or move on to a better job. At this age, all I want is to somehow feel that I have made a little and indirect contribution to your success. That‚Äôs what motivates me!

Norizan Sharif, Skorlah Online, OpenLearning Contentpreneur

Building on his expertise and passion, he curated a series of online courses delivered in Bahasa Malaysia as an avenue for graduates, high school leavers, and unemployed youth to develop key communication and interpersonal skills.

To date, he has built four courses on Interpersonal and Human Relations, Persuasive Communication, Conflict Resolution and Personal Branding and Marketing. These bite-sized self-development courses are concise, digestible and practical, and have amassed a community of over 3,000 learners.

Norizan is just one of the changemakers in Malaysian education who are offering online courses to the public on OpenLearning. From this Malaysian Sign Language course, to this online water safety course, to this course that helps Malaysians land jobs‚Äîthese Contentpreneurs don‚Äôt look to be slowing down anytime soon.

To understand the appeal of these online courses for learners, we asked a few of them about why they chose to join Norizan‚Äôs courses. Here‚Äôs what they said:

It‚Äôs a flexible way of learning.

A universal reason for learning new skills online is the flexibility of being able to choose what, where, and when to learn.

One of Norizan‚Äôs learners is Danish Putera, who completed the Interpersonal and Human Relations course. Being in his first year of a foundation in Computer Science, he has already started supplementing his learning with online courses, saying he joined the course to ‚Äúlearn new skills and knowledge as a preparation to face the future.‚Äù

Danish describes his experience of online learning as ‚Äúa flexible way of learning.‚Äù He felt he was able to learn anywhere, and at any time, adding that ‚ÄúI can also learn at my own pace as different people learn at different paces.‚Äù

It adds value to my career and resum√©.

How do you write a resume for a changing job market?

Beyond listing your experiences and certifications, it will be important to collect evidence of your achievements ‚Äì from group work, to completed projects and assignments. Online courses are the perfect medium for you to showcase and track your progress. On OpenLearning, this information is stored and linked to your profile in real-time via your OpenLearning Portfolio.

Hariz Jamaludin, who works in the estate management industry, decided to take Norizan‚Äôs course on Interpersonal and Human Relations and found it to be compact and applicable to his career pathway.

In a later LinkedIn post, Hariz said: ‚ÄúWhen the instructor came up with a second online course, I did not hesitate to sign up as I found it beneficial for my career and personal development.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe certificate issued at the end of the course is an added value to my resume. With affordable fees, I recommend those who want to add value to their resume to attend these courses.‚Äù

I realise how important these skills are.

For Amy Mastura binti Hamzah, her background in business administration necessitated her decision to complete three of Norizan‚Äôs courses: Interpersonal and Human Relations, Persuasive Communication, and Conflict Resolution.

‚ÄúThe reason why I took these courses is that I realized how important interpersonal and human relations, persuasive communication, and conflict resolution are nowadays. Especially for those who are required to interact with people on a daily basis.‚Äù

Amy also noted the flexibility of learning online: ‚ÄúI felt great because I can take a course from the comfort of my office or home. Even with a busy schedule, I can find some spare time to take a course or study for it.‚Äù

She, too, found that the courses added value to her life: ‚ÄúI want to change my attitude, develop skills, and increase my knowledge. I hope that by joining all these three courses, I can improve myself to be a better person.‚Äù

In conclusion

The micro-learning revolution has reached Malaysia‚Äôs shores‚Äîand whether you‚Äôre a learner or a course creator, you can be a part of it too. These flexible, career-boosting courses are here to stay, especially since more and more learners are considering this option to stay current and thrive in an uncertain, fast-changing world.

For learners:

Keep an eye on Norizan‚Äôs latest courses for self-development, all available in Bahasa Malaysia.

Check out UPSKIL.my for more online courses from other Malaysian creators, or browse OpenLearning.com for a global marketplace of online courses.

If you loved completing any of these courses, let us know by sharing your experience or certificate and tagging us on Instagram, Facebook, Twitter or LinkedIn.
